title: Simulation Analysis
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(openintro)

This data, Gender Stereotypes in 5-7 year old Children, was found in the R open intro package. It reports the results of an experimental study conducted in 2017 by Lin Bian that tested whether some children were more likely to choose someone of their own gender when asked to identify a “smart” or “nice” individual in an image. The stereotype variable gives the proportion of trials where each child chose a gender target that matched their own gender. I will focus specifically on trials where the children were shown images of adults and asked to point out the person who appeared to be smart, and compare results between the male and female genders.
My research question: Are young females less likely to identify adults of their own gender as smart than young males?

gender_stereo <- children_gender_stereo[["2"]]

stereo_obs <- gender_stereo |>
  filter(trait == "smart", target == "adults") |>
  group_by(gender) |>
  summarize(mean_stereotype = mean(stereotype)) |>
  mutate(difference = mean_stereotype[gender == "male"] - mean_stereotype[gender == "female"]) |>
  pull(difference)

stereo_obs

[1] 0.09722222 0.09722222


Ho: μfemale = μmale (μmale - μfemale = 0) Ha: μmale - μfemale > 0

simulate_choices <- function(rep, num_tests) {
  
  female_choices <- sample(c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1), size = num_tests, replace = TRUE)
  male_choices <- sample(c(0, 0.25, 0.5, 0.75, 1), size = num_tests, replace = TRUE)
  return(mean(male_choices) - mean(female_choices))
}
set.seed(47)
num_exper <- 5000
distribution <- map_dbl(1:num_exper, simulate_choices, num_tests = 144)


# p-value
sum(distribution >= stereo_obs) / num_exper

[1] 0.013



# visualize null sampling distribution
distribution |>
  data.frame() |>
  ggplot(aes(x = distribution)) +
  geom_histogram() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = stereo_obs, color = "red") + 
  labs(
    title = "Sampling Distribution when Ho is True",
    subtitle = "aka no difference between gender picks",
    x = "mean difference in proportion of stereotype by gender"
  )








This plot displays the null sampling distribution of
Source:
Bian L, Leslie SJ, Cimpian A. 2017. “Gender stereotypes about intellectual ability emerge early and influence children’s interests”. Science 355:6323 (389-391). https://www.science.org/doi/10.1126/science.aah6524.

title: Text Analysis
Olympics
text:
Question: How does the average age of Olympic participants vary by sport and how has that changed over time? (I have selected 6 sports from the data for readability purposes.)
Code:

knitr::opts_chunk$set(error = TRUE)

library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

olympics <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-08-06/olympics.csv')


selected_sports <- filter(olympics, sport == "Swimming" | sport == "Gymnastics" 
                          | sport == "Equestrianism" | sport == "Diving" | sport == "Weightlifting" | sport == "Speed Skating")

new_olympics <- selected_sports |>
  group_by(year, sport) |>
  mutate(avg_age = mean(age, na.rm = TRUE))

ggplot(new_olympics, aes(x = year, y = avg_age, color = sport)) + 
  geom_line() + 
  labs(
    title = "Average Age of Olympic Participants by Sport",
    x = "Olympic Year", 
    y = "Average age of Participants"
  )








Analysis:
From this plot, we can see that the average age of Equestrian Olympians has been consistently 5+ years greater than the averages of the other five sports shown between 1890 and 2010. Notably, where most sports saw a large increase in average age between the late 1800s and early 1900s, equestrianism shows a large decrease in average participant age during these years.
Among the other sports, swimming consistently had the lowest average age of competitors, until Gymnastics surpassed it in the mid-1980s. Meanwhile, weightlifting has average ages of its Olympians most consistently on the high end, but still nowhere near the equestrian average.
Overall, there does not appear to be a very strong relationship between year and average age of Olympic participants that is consistent across these sports, except an all-around dip in age around 1980.
Link to Data: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2024/2024-08-06

title: Cheese!
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(ggplot2)

cheeses <- readr::read_csv('https://raw.githubusercontent.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/master/data/2024/2024-06-04/cheeses.csv')


ggplot(cheeses, aes(x = rind, color = color)) + 
  geom_bar() + 
  labs(
    title = "Cheese Rind Count by Color",
    x = "Rind Type",
    y = "Count"
  ) + 
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))








Link to Data: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday/tree/master/data/2024/2024-06-04

title: Maren Rusk
text: Hi! My name is Maren, and I’m a student at Pomona College, class of 2027. I am studying Mathematics and Data Science with an interest in politics. Outside of school, I swim for the Pomona-Pitzer swim team and play the piano.
